title: Donald Trump's year of tweeting dangerously
authors: Nolan D. Mccaskill, Eli Stokols, Hadas Gold
content:
Donald Trump didn ’ t just dominate media coverage and polls since announcing his White House bid in June . He dominated Twitter , too — a surprisingly effective strategy that saw him drive entire news cycles merely by blasting out choppy pronouncements on his Samsung Galaxy smartphone , often at odd hours .
Trump enters the new year with more than 5.5 million Twitter followers and a slimmed-down campaign operation that he says is $ 35 million under budget . The billionaire businessman has saved millions on ad buys by voicing his always unfiltered , sometimes inflammatory comments to a mass audience through his timeline , with a reach far exceeding most of his competitors .
███ examined thousands of Trump ’ s tweets from mid-July through mid-December — 3,249 tweets and retweets , to be exact . What we found is a tug of war between the Manhattan mogul ’ s famous ego and his equally infamous id : bragging about his poll numbers , crowd sizes , and TV ratings in one moment , then viciously attacking his rivals and critics the next .
Trump ’ s obsession with polls leaps out most of all . Trump sent roughly 330 poll-related messages into the Twittersphere throughout the five-month span , typically touting his first-place position in early-state and national polls , ripping any “ dishonest ” media organizations that report a survey that suggests otherwise or bashing “ failing ” candidates for their poll positions .
On Dec. 15 alone , Trump tweeted about surveys seven times . “ Isn ’ t it amazing that @ CNN paid a fortune for an Iowa poll , which shows me in first place over Cruz by 13 % , 33 % to 20 % - then doesn ’ t use it , ” Trump said , referencing Texas Sen. Ted Cruz . “ Why isn ’ t anyone using the @ CNN Iowa poll with me having a big lead . They only want to use the one negative poll ( 2nd place ) , ” he followed up . “ Dishonest press . ”
Trump then trained his sights on a familiar target , this time for misstating his lead over Ted Cruz in a national poll . “ . @ megynkelly , the most overrated anchor at @ FoxNews , worked hard to explain away the new Monmouth poll 41 to 14 or 27 pt lead , ” Trump tweeted . “ She said 15 ! ” Kelly “ is very bad at math , ” Trump charged . “ She was totally unable to figure out the difference between me and Cruz in the new Monmouth Poll 41to14. ” All told , Trump has tweeted about the Fox News anchorwoman 66 times .
But Trump is more likely to cast his cruel criticisms toward his White House rivals than at the media . His most frequent target ? Jeb Bush . Trump went after the former Florida governor 97 times , compared to 65 hits on Hillary Clinton and 49 on Florida Sen. Marco Rubio .
“ . @ JebBush is totally lost -- he spends too much time managing the bloated staff of his campaign & not enough talking about America ’ s future , ” Trump said in one of two Bush-blasting tweets on Oct. 24 . “ . @ JebBush had a tiny 300 person crowd at Senator Tim Scott ’ s forum . I had thousands , and they had real passion ! ” Trump tweeted next , alongside a picture of a crowd taken from a stage .
Large crowds were also a consistent theme Trump couldn ’ t resist tweeting about . He boasted 45 times about the TV ratings he brings in and made more than 80 references to his crowds . “ Just read that ‘ Trump ’ has the largest ( and I add most enthusiastic ) crowds , ” he remarked on Sept. 30 . “ Tonight I will be in New Hampshire - the place will be packed ! ”
But Trump isn ’ t always on the offensive . He praises media outlets for favorable coverage and retweets his followers more than anything — our tally totaled 1,778 retweets . Perhaps most surprising is that Trump often tweets like a typical politician , promoting his new book , “ Crippled America , ” more than 30 times and regularly informing the world of his upcoming campaign stops and TV appearances while also frequently thanking his supporters .
“ People have got to stop working to be so politically correct and focus all of their energy on finding solutions to very complex problems ! ” Trump wrote on Dec. 14 in one of his thousand-plus more innocuous tweets . Later in the day he retweeted former talk-show host Piers Morgan , who said a Trump-Clinton race would be “ the greatest presidential battle in history , ” and thanked Scottie Hughes , a Trump supporter , for her “ fantastic ” interview on CNN in which she said “ nice words . ”
In fact , one of Trump ’ s most popular tweets of 2015 — his Nov. 13 offer of “ prayers ” for the victims of the Paris attacks , which generated 14,263 retweets and 30,628 likes — was a completely normal political sentiment . ( Somewhat more popular : His tweet asking “ Is our president insane ? ” for letting in Syrian refugees . )
Trump ’ s social game is a bewildering blend of brash and bland . But overall , his Twitter feed is an astonishing campaign lesson in how to command the world 's biggest stage : the Internet . “ I understand social media maybe better than anybody , ever , ” he boasted in November . “ Somebody said I ’ m the Ernest Hemingway of 140 characters. ” Maybe so . But Trump ’ s online moveable feast isn ’ t just connecting with millions of readers — it could help put him in the White House .
Kristen Hayford , Hanna Trudo , Jesse Rifkin and Noah Weiland contributed .
